--- title: "§5 Spinning the Reels 🎰" subtitle: "Introduction to Tidyverse" format: html: toc: true code-fold: false code-tools: true code-link: true highlight-style: github include-in-header: text: | execute: freeze: auto --- Welcome to the exciting world of tidyverse! In this chapter, we'll build on our knowledge of R by exploring the tidyverse, a collection of R packages designed for data science. We'll create a virtual slot machine to demonstrate the power and simplicity of tidyverse functions. ::: {.callout-tip} ## Learning Objectives - 📦 Understand the basics of tidyverse and its core packages - 🔄 Learn to manipulate data with dplyr functions - 📊 Visualize data using ggplot2 - 🎰 Build a virtual slot machine using tidyverse functions ::: # Introduction to Tidyverse 📦 Tidyverse is a collection of R packages that work together harmoniously for data manipulation, exploration, and visualization. Let's start by loading the tidyverse: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # install.packages('tidyverse') library(tidyverse) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ── ✔ dplyr 1.1.4 ✔ readr 2.1.5 ✔ forcats 1.0.0 ✔ stringr 1.5.1 ✔ ggplot2 3.5.1 ✔ tibble 3.2.1 ✔ lubridate 1.9.3 ✔ tidyr 1.3.1 ✔ purrr 1.0.2 ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ✖ dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ℹ Use the conflicted package () to force all conflicts to become errors ``` ::: ::: The core tidyverse includes packages like dplyr (for data manipulation) and ggplot2 (for data visualization). ## Learning Check 🏁
# Data Manipulation with dplyr 🔄 Let's revisit our deck of cards from the previous chapter, but this time using dplyr functions: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create the deck deck <- tibble( suit = rep(c("Hearts", "Diamonds", "Clubs", "Spades"), each = 13), rank = rep(c("Ace", 2:10, "Jack", "Queen", "King"), times = 4), value = rep(1:13, times = 4) ) # View the first few cards deck %>% head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 3 suit rank value 1 Hearts Ace 1 2 Hearts 2 2 3 Hearts 3 3 4 Hearts 4 4 5 Hearts 5 5 6 Hearts 6 6 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Find all face cards face_cards <- deck %>% filter(rank %in% c("Jack", "Queen", "King")) # Calculate average value avg_value <- deck %>% summarise(mean_value = mean(value)) # Add color column deck <- deck %>% mutate(color = if_else(suit %in% c("Hearts", "Diamonds"), "Red", "Black")) ``` ::: ## Hands-On Coding 💻 Try the following: 1. Use `filter()` to find all the Aces in the deck. 2. Use `arrange()` to sort the deck by suit, then by value. 3. Use `group_by()` and `summarise()` to find the average value for each suit.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Find all Aces aces <- deck %>% filter(rank == "Ace") # Sort deck sorted_deck <- deck %>% arrange(suit, value) # Average value by suit avg_by_suit <- deck %>% group_by(suit) %>% summarise(avg_value = mean(value)) ``` :::
# Data Visualization with ggplot2 📊 Now, let's visualize our deck using ggplot2: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(deck, aes(x = suit, fill = color)) + geom_bar() + labs(title = "Distribution of Cards by Suit", x = "Suit", y = "Count") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](05-tidyverse_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Learning Check 🏁
# Building a Slot Machine 🎰 Now, let's use our tidyverse skills to create a virtual slot machine! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Create slot machine symbols symbols <- tibble( symbol = c("Cherry", "Bell", "Bar", "Seven", "Diamond"), probability = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.15, 0.1, 0.05), payout = c(10, 20, 50, 100, 200) ) # Function to spin the slot machine spin_slot_machine <- function() { set.seed(NULL) # Ensure randomness result <- symbols %>% slice_sample(n = 3, weight_by = probability, replace = TRUE) if (n_distinct(result$symbol) == 1) { winnings <- result$payout[1] message(paste("Jackpot! You won", winnings, "coins!")) } else { message("Sorry, try again!") } return(result) } # Spin the slot machine spin_result <- spin_slot_machine() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Sorry, try again! ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} print(spin_result) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 × 3 symbol probability payout 1 Seven 0.1 100 2 Bell 0.3 20 3 Bell 0.3 20 ``` ::: ::: ## Hands-On Coding 💻 Try the following: 1. Modify the `spin_slot_machine()` function to allow for different numbers of reels. 2. Create a function that simulates playing the slot machine multiple times and calculates the average payout. 3. Use ggplot2 to visualize the distribution of symbols after many spins.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Modified spin function spin_slot_machine <- function(n_reels = 3) { set.seed(NULL) result <- symbols %>% slice_sample(n = n_reels, weight_by = probability, replace = TRUE) if (n_distinct(result$symbol) == 1) { winnings <- result$payout[1] message(paste("Jackpot! You won", winnings, "coins!")) } else { message("Sorry, try again!") } return(result) } # Simulate multiple spins simulate_spins <- function(n_spins = 1000) { results <- map_df(1:n_spins, ~spin_slot_machine()) avg_payout <- results %>% group_by(symbol) %>% summarise(count = n()) %>% left_join(symbols, by = "symbol") %>% mutate(total_payout = count*payout) %>% summarise(avg_payout = sum(total_payout) / n_spins) %>% pull(avg_payout) return(list(results = results, avg_payout = avg_payout)) } # Visualize distribution of symbols visualize_spins <- function(n_spins = 1000) { simulation <- simulate_spins(n_spins) ggplot(simulation$results, aes(x = symbol)) + geom_bar(fill = "skyblue") + labs(title = paste("Distribution of Symbols after", n_spins, "Spins"), x = "Symbol", y = "Count") + theme_minimal() } # Run the simulation and visualization set.seed(123) # for reproducibility sim_results <- simulate_spins(1000) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Jackpot! You won 10 coins! ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Jackpot! You won 10 coins! ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! Sorry, try again! ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Jackpot! # Conclusion In this chapter, we've introduced the tidyverse and applied its powerful functions to manipulate and visualize data. We've built on our previous knowledge of dice and cards to create a virtual slot machine, demonstrating how tidyverse can be used for more complex data operations and analysis. These skills will be invaluable as you continue your journey in data analysis and visualization with R. In the next chapter, we'll explore more advanced tidyverse functions and apply them to real-world datasets in digital humanities!
